thread.title: Kite surfer drowns at Semaphore
thread.title_full: Kite surfer drowns at Semaphore | The Advertiser

author: Sam Kelton Police Reporter
title: Kite surfer drowns at Semaphore
text:
A KITE surfer has drowned at Semaphore beach.
The victim, a man who witnesses said looked to be aged in his 60s, drowned between the Semaphore and Largs Bay jetties shortly before 12.30pm this afternoon.
He was pulled from the water by a fellow kite surfer after he drifted more than 300 metres towards Semaphore.
He was kite surfing on the northern side of Largs Pier jetty.
Louisa Norman, 34, and her partner, Josh Picken, were walking their dogs along the beach when they noticed a man dragging something in the water.
“As I got close to him I realised he was dragging a body,” Ms Norman said.
“We helped drag the man out and commence CPR.”
Ms Norman said that the accident happened some time before and that the man’s body drifted in the waves before he was brought to shore by a fellow kite surfer.
“The ambulances arrived probably five or 10 minutes after he pulled him out of the water and as I understand it someone on the jetty saw the accident and called the ambulance about 30 minutes prior,” she said.
“I think they were walking along the jetty and heard a loud bang — I think it was the bang of the sail hitting the water.”
Mr Picken, 31, who watched his partner frantically trying to save the man’s life, said the kite surfer did not look like he had suffered a serious accident.
“He didn’t look like he had any trauma,” he said.
“I’m not sure if he had an accident. He was a kite surfer in his 60s I’d say and he had no family or friends around from what I could see, but there were a group of kite surfers in the area that were quite close.
“The people that saw it happen on the jetty said he drifted away and it was about 300m before the guy got to him.”
Ms Norman said that the incident shows that first aid experience can be required at any time in any situation.
“It just goes to show that more people need to learn first aid and be willing to step in,” she said.
“Because at the end of the day — it’s a Sunday, enjoying a sport he’s passionate about and the more people who are confident in helping and trying to help, the better.
“The man had been dragging the body for a long time and no one was there to help sooner. Apparently, from what I could see there were no lifeguards or response and you can’t help thinking if there were, it might have had a better outcome.”
Scene where a man believed to be in his 60s died and was pulled from the water by a fellow kite surfers. #NewsADL pic.twitter.com/LoEFVZyryl
— Sam Kelton (@kelts82) August 9, 2015
